The Minister of Health reminded the Cabinetthat when the cuts to certain branches of the PublicService were limited to not more than 10 per cent.(Cabinet fjl (31), Conclusion 1), he had given warning that difficulties with the Insurance Doctors were tobe anticipated. Since then the Insurance Acts Gom-mittee had come to see him and had reminded him thatthey had accepted the reduction in the doctors'remuneration from 9/- to 8/- on the understandingthat no-one else would be let off. They now pressed for a reduction in the cuts to doctors. One of thereasons they gave had been that the capitation feesdid not' represent the net income of medical men, whohad other expenses incidental to their profession.He had replied that the public would not accept that reason. As a result of the interview, however, hehad seen the Chancellor of the Exchequer, who had agreed to accept a cut of 10 per cent, instead of a deduction of one-ninth, as set forth in the white paper (Cmd. 3952 (1931)). He had then informed theIns\france Acts Committee by letter that this altera-tion would be sanctioned. The Insurance Acts Committeehad come to him again and said they could not recommend the doctors to accept this concession, but he proposedto hold to the 10 per cent, and had made a statement to that effect in Debate the same day.The Cabinet took note of, and approved,the above arrangements.
